Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Situation2: They plan to attend a family ceremony, making sure to arrive on time and wear appropriate attire.
Story: I watched my stepbrother lace up his sneakers, his skateboard already perched at the top of the steep, cracked ramp in our neighborhood park. He grinned at me, excitement in his eyes, and I felt the familiar tug of responsibility—my mom always said I should look out for him, make sure he didn’t get hurt. But my phone buzzed with a reminder: the family puja was in less than an hour. I was supposed to be home, dressed in my kurta, helping set up the offerings and lighting the lamps. My stepbrother begged me to stay, to spot him as he tried the new trick, but I could already hear my dad’s voice in my head, reminding me how important it was to honor our traditions and be on time for the ceremony. My heart pounded as I stood between the ramp and the path home, torn between keeping my stepbrother safe and fulfilling my duty as a Hindu. I didn’t know which expectation weighed heavier, but I knew I couldn’t meet both.
